author: Benedict Brook
title: Sickies: Australians take more than two million days off work due to self-inflicted injuries
text:
SOME sickies you just can’t help. 
When the flu is doing the rounds, the only solution is to huddle under a blanket watching repeats of Ellen to save the rest of your workplace from the dreaded lurgy.
But new research has revealed a strain of self-inflicted sickies is costing employers dearly. And yet, people are getting injured while trying to get healthier.
What better way to wind down from the working day than taking out your stresses on the footy field?
An estimated two-in-three Australians over the age of 15 take part in organised sport.
However, a survey released to news.com.au claims employers are paying for our love of getting physical with millions of sickies taken due to self-inflicted sporting injuries.
Nearly 14 per cent of Aussies have admitted to taking time off due to injuries which occurred on the cricket pitch, squash court and footy field.
Two and half million people were forced to take some time off work due to aches and sprains sustained in the name of sporting prowess.
Almost 200,000 people had to give up work entirely due to wrecking their bodies in their recreation time.
Amateur footy players, like the team at Port Districts Football Club are the most likely to get injured. Picture: Tricia Watkinson. Source: News Corp Australia 
The research was undertaken by comparison website finder.com.au which surveyed 2000 people.
Finder.com.au money expert, Bessie Hassan, said while Australians had a reputation for being sports obsessed, physical activity didn’t come without its risks.
“Football is the leading cause of injuries requiring a trip to emergency — with around one-third of all sports injury hospitalisations associated with playing various codes of football.”
Physical pain wasn’t the only ailment the injured suffered from. It was a kick in the hip pocket as well, she said.
“Sport is a very big part of the Aussie psyche so it’s no surprise how many people are injured every year — what is surprising is how many people miss out on pay because of it.”
Of those injured, 21 per cent took a combination of sick and annual leave while 16 per cent had to had to take unpaid leave while they were recovered leaving them out of pocket.
Men were more likely to need time off work than woman, with 16 per cent having chucked a sporting sickie. Only 13 per cent of women had done the same.
Watching a game of amateur netball, this lady is probably the least likely person on the lot to have an injury. Source: News Corp Australia 
Men were also most likely to have to give up work completely due to a serious sporting injury.
According to absence management experts Direct Health Solutions, absenteeism costs the Australian economy more than $33 billion in wages and lost productivity every year.
In 2016, absenteeism increased by 0.9 days to 9.5 days per employee, at an average cost of $3608.
On Australia Day alone, sickies were expected to cost the economy $54m in lost productivity. 
“Misusing sick leave erodes trust in the workplace, puts extra strain on colleagues doing the right thing and leaves people short of sick leave when they genuinely need it,” Paul Dundon, DHS Managing Director said.
The organisation reckons it can cut sick leave by 25 per cent. Perhaps by banning after work sport?
Australian Bureau of Statistics data shows 11.1 million adults take part in sport or another form of physical recreation each year but that figure has been steadily decreasing.
Participation generally decreased with age with teenagers the most active.
Canberrans are the most physical with three-quarters getting some exercise. But Queenslanders are the laggards with little more than half getting hot and sweaty.
